definition: acrobatics/jugglery/cheap trick/game
handle
to hold/to contain/to grasp/to take hold of/handle/particle marking the following noun as a direct object/classifier for objects with handle/classifier for small objects: handful
trick/drama/play/show/CL:齣|出[chu1],場|场[chang3],臺|台[tai2]
sinister plot/dirty trick/cheap trick
to perform magic/to do magic tricks/prestidigitation

sentences.english: Feints and stratagems are the stuff of chess.
sentences.chinese: 佯裝與計謀都是下象棋常耍的把戲。

sentences.english: On the one hand, I can see that this is a pretty cool gadget.
sentences.chinese: 從這方面講，我認爲它是一個相當出色的小把戲。

sentences.english: The lap-dog knew many tricks, and was a great favourite with his master.
sentences.chinese: 哈巴狗卻會很多的鬼把戲，深得主人的寵愛。

sentences.english: You can't teach an old dog new tricks.
It's a behavior trick for younger kids.
sentences.chinese: 這對你的小小孩兒來說是個“小把戲”。

sentences.english: It was a 11)dirty trick, but it killed old Phoebe.
sentences.chinese: 這實在是種卑鄙把戲，可差點兒把老菲比笑死。

sentences.english: You can always go trick-or-treating during the afternoon or to the mall.
sentences.chinese: 你可以一直在下午或商業街上耍那唬人的把戲。

sentences.english: You go with those juggler, all went to some place?
sentences.chinese: 你跟那些耍把戲的走了，都到了些什麼地方呢？

sentences.english: This year, there were no tricks and no serious injuries.
sentences.chinese: 今年的比賽沒有騙人把戲，也沒有人重傷。

sentences.english: My dead dog, Bobby, doesn't do tricks anymore.
sentences.chinese: 我的死狗博比再也不能玩那些小把戲了。

sentences.english: This little trick is like a mini reflexology session.
sentences.chinese: 這項小把戲就像是種迷你反射療法。

sentences.english: Lester had been famous among the line workers for a magic trick.
sentences.chinese: 萊斯特在一線員工中以一種魔術把戲而聞名。

sentences.english: The proud look on my 4-year-old son’s face when he learns a new skill.
sentences.chinese: 4歲兒子學會新把戲時的，他臉上的自豪感。

sentences.english: They cunningly played the game of sham peace.
sentences.chinese: 他們狡滑地玩弄假和平的把戲。

definition: aloof/indifferent/unconcerned
to play tricks on/to make fun of/to tease
lit. a deluge of heavenly flowers (idiom)/fig. extravagant embellishments/hype
to put on an act (idiom); to show affectation/to indulge in histrionics
to obstinately persist in going about things the wrong way (idiom)
item (on a program)
to judge
to tease a woman by pretending to be displeased with her/to flirt with a member of the opposite sex/to banter flirtatiously
lit. find a stage, put on a comedy (idiom); to join in the fun/to play along according to local conditions
to show off/to make a display of
graceful words, flowery speech (idiom); elegant but insincere words/cheating wheedling/dishonest rhetoric
In order to capture, one must let loose./to loosen the reins only to grasp them better
bad habit (e.g. nose-picking)/petty maneuver/dirty trick/gamesmanship
trick/ruse/crafty scheme
to deceive/to cheat
sensitive/tactful
